					<article class="clearfix full-article has-hero-image  time_article non-metered" id="article-4350398" data-article="4350398" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
	<header class="article-header">
		



		<section class="tags ">
			<a class="brand-tag brand-time-tag" href="http://time.com/">TIME</a>
			
				<a class="section-tag" itemprop="articleSection" href="http://time.com/health/" data-event="section-health">Health</a>
				<a class="topic-tag" itemprop="articleSection" href="http://time.com/tag/cancer/" data-event="tag-cancer" >Cancer</a>
		</section>


		<h1 class="article-title" itemprop="headline">Cell Phone-Cancer Link Seen in Rat Study</h1>


		
		

	<div class="article-sub-headline">
		<div class="article-meta">
					<ul class="article-authors">
							<li class="article-author ">
								<span class="byline"><a itemprop="author" href="http://time.com/author/alexandra-sifferlin/">Alexandra Sifferlin</a></span>
								<a class="author-twitter" target="_blank" href="https://twitter.com/acsifferlin">@acsifferlin</a>
							</li>
					</ul>

			<time class="publish-date" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2016-05-27 10:38:06" pubdate>May 27, 2016</time>
			
			
		</div>
		<div class="social-links">
			<a class="expand-share" href="javascript:void 0;" title="Click to view article share options">SHARE</a>
		<span class="social-links-tooltip">
			<a class="time-icons time-icons-mail social-link-mail" href="mailto:?subject=Cell%20Phone-Cancer%20Link%20Seen%20in%20Rat%20Study%20%7C%20TIME&body=Cell%20Phone-Cancer%20Link%20Seen%20in%20Rat%20Study%0A%0AMore%20research%20is%20needed%20to%20fully%20understand%20the%20link%0A%0Ahttp%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4350398%2Fcell-phones-brain-heart-cancer-rats%2F%3Fxid%3Demailshare" data-event="email" title="Click to Email this article"></a>
			<a class="time-icons time-icons-fb social-link-fb popup" href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4350398%2Fcell-phones-brain-heart-cancer-rats%2F%3Fxid%3Dfbshare" data-event="fb-share" title="Click to post this article to Facebook"></a>

			<a class="time-icons time-icons-whatsapp social-link-whatsapp visible-micro-inline-block visible-small-inline-block" onclick="window.location='whatsapp://send?text=Study%20links%20cell%20phones%20to%20cancer%20in%20rats%0Ahttp%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4350398%2Fcell-phones-brain-heart-cancer-rats%2F%3Fxid%3Dwhatsappshare';" data-event="whatsapp" title="Click to share this article on Whatsapp" data-action="share/whatsapp/share"></a>

			<a class="time-icons time-icons-linkedin social-link-linkedin popup" href="http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4350398%2Fcell-phones-brain-heart-cancer-rats%2F%3Fxid%3Dlinkedinshare&title=Cell+Phone-Cancer+Link+Seen+in+Rat+Study" data-event="linkedin" title="Click to post this article to LinkedIn"></a>
		</span>

	<section class="article-body" itemprop="articleBody">
				<h2 class="article-excerpt" itemprop="alternativeHeadline">More research is needed to fully understand the link</h2>

					<span class="read-video-article collapsed">+ READ ARTICLE</span>
					<div class="video-content ">
							<figure class="primary-video-wrapper video-brightcove" itemprop="video"><div class="video-container"><video id="brightcove-player-4915987369001" data-video-id="4915987369001" data-account="293884104" data-player="SJa0Thl7" data-embed="default" controls preload="auto" class="video-js responsive-video"></video></div></figure>
					<aside class="right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad"><div class="right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module"><div class="right-rail__ad" id="right-rail__ad-4350398"></div></div><br />
<div class="OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module video-2" data-src="http://time.com/4350398/cell-phones-brain-heart-cancer-rats/" data-widget-id="SB_4" data-ob-template="timemag"></div></aside>
<p>An important <a href="http://biorxiv.org/content/biorxiv/early/2016/05/26/055699.full.pdf" target="_blank">new study</a> has linked cell phone radiation to cancers in the brain and heart.</p>
<p>The new research was conducted on rats by the U.S. National Toxicology Program, which exposed rats to radiofrequency radiation that comes from cell phones for about nine hours a day for seven days a week. They found that the exposed rats were more likely to develop cancers, specifically malignant gliomas—a tumor of glial cells in the brain—and tumors in the heart.</p>
<p>The study was reviewed by experts at the National Institutes of Health (NIH), and the authors say more research on the link will emerge in the next couple years. There are some important caveats to the new report. A study in rats is never directly translational to humans. It does, however, give researchers evidence that can lead to further research on the impact cell-phone radiation has on people. The findings were also most statistically significant for male rats.<br />
<div class="article-video ad_brightcove_video right-rail-adjacent"><div id="ad_brightcove" class="ad_brightcove_video-wrapper"></div></div></p>
<p>Other research has seen a link between cell phones and cancer, though research overall remains limited. The World Health Organization’s International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) classified cell phone use and other radiofrequency electromagnetic fields as a <a href="http://www.cancer.gov/news-events/press-releases/2011/IARCcellphoneMay2011" target="_blank">possible carcinogen</a> in 2011. “<span class="s1">This study in mice and rats is under review by additional experts,” the NIH said in a statement about the findings. “It is important to note that previous human, observational data collected in earlier, large-scale population-based studies have found limited evidence of an increased risk for developing cancer from cell phone use.”</span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1"><div class="newsletter-shortcode health">
<form action="https://pages.email.time.com/web-opt-in/" method="post" target="time_brief_popup">
    <label class="intro"><small>Sign up for</small> <img src="https://s0.wp.com/wp-content/themes/vip/plugins/lazy-load/images/1x1.trans.gif" data-lazy-src="https://s0.wp.com/wp-content/themes/vip/time2014/img/newsletter-shortcode/time-health-logo-140.png" width="70"><noscript><img src="https://s0.wp.com/wp-content/themes/vip/time2014/img/newsletter-shortcode/time-health-logo-140.png" width="70" /></noscript><small class="and-more">and more</small> <small class="example"> <a href="http://time.com/newsletter/health/" target="_blank">view example</a></small></label>
    <input type="hidden" class="newsletter-name-health" name="newsletter_name" value="HEALTH">
    <input type="hidden" class="newsletter-source-health" name="source" value="shortcode">
    <input type="hidden" name="success_url" value="https://pages.email.time.com/thank-you/">
    <input type="text" class="text input-field email newsletter-email-health" name="email_address" placeholder="Email" title="Valid email address required" onfocus="onloadCallback('newsletter-recaptcha-health')">
    <div id="newsletter-recaptcha-health" class="newsletter-recaptcha"></div>
    <input type="submit" class="submit button newsletter-email-submit-button" data-newslettertext="health" value="Submit">

</form>
</div></span></p>
<p>Other studies have produced conflicting results. <a href="http://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/causes-prevention/risk/radiation/cell-phones-fact-sheet" target="_blank">One cohort study</a> in Denmark looked at billing information from 358,000 cell phone users and then compared it to brain-tumor data from a national cancer registry. That study did not find a link between the two. <a href="http://www.cancerepidemiology.net/article/S1877-7821(16)30050-9/abstract" target="_blank">Another recent study</a> published in May looked at incidence of brain cancer in Australia from 1982 to 2013 and did not find an uptick in cancer cases with the introduction of cells phones. Still, <a href="http://healthland.time.com/2011/02/22/study-cell-phones-cause-changes-in-brain-activity/">other government-funded studies</a> have made connections between cell phones’ electromagnetic fields and changes in brain activity. <a href="http://time.com/2850594/guys-your-smartphone-is-hurting-your-sperm/">And a June 2014 study</a> found that radiation from cell phones can lower men’s sperm mobility by 8% and sperm viability by 9%.</p>
<p>The NIH <a href="http://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/causes-prevention/risk/radiation/cell-phones-fact-sheet" target="_blank">says</a> part of the reason research so far has been inconsistent is that there are various factors that can influence the results of a study. For instance, brain cancers are notoriously difficult to study due to their high mortality rates, and studies are also subject to issues like inaccurate reporting. There are also changes over time in the type of cell phones available as well as how much people use them.</p>
<p>The researchers say this new report is unlikely to be the final word on the possible risks of cell phone radiation, and more data from their research is anticipated to be released in fall 2017.</p>

					</div>
	</section>

They found that the exposed rats were more likely to develop cancers, specifically malignant gliomas—a tumor of glial cells in the brain—and tumors in the heart.<\/p>\n<p>The study was reviewed by experts at the National Institutes of Health (NIH), and the authors say more research on the link will emerge in the next couple years. There are some important caveats to the new report. A study in rats is never directly translational to humans. It does, however, give researchers evidence that can lead to further research on the impact cell-phone radiation has on people. The findings were also most statistically significant for male rats.<br \/>\n<div class=\"article-video ad_brightcove_video right-rail-adjacent\"><div id=\"ad_brightcove\" class=\"ad_brightcove_video-wrapper\"><\/div><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Other research has seen a link between cell phones and cancer, though research overall remains limited. The World Health Organization’s International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) classified cell phone use and other radiofrequency electromagnetic fields as a <a href=\"http:\/\/www.cancer.gov\/news-events\/press-releases\/2011\/IARCcellphoneMay2011\" target=\"_blank\">possible carcinogen<\/a> in 2011. “<span class=\"s1\">This study in mice and rats is under review by additional experts,” the NIH said in a statement about the findings. “It is important to note that previous human, observational data collected in earlier, large-scale population-based studies have found limited evidence of an increased risk for developing cancer from cell phone use.”<\/span><\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\"><div class=\"newsletter-shortcode health\">\n<form action=\"https:\/\/pages.email.time.com\/web-opt-in\/\" method=\"post\" target=\"time_brief_popup\">\n    <label class=\"intro\"><small>Sign up for<\/small> <img class=\"submit button newsletter-email-submit-button\" data-newslettertext=\"health\" value=\"Submit\">\n\n<\/form>\n<\/div><\/span><\/p>\n<p>Other studies have produced conflicting results. <a href=\"http:\/\/www.cancer.gov\/about-cancer\/causes-prevention\/risk\/radiation\/cell-phones-fact-sheet\" target=\"_blank\">One cohort study<\/a> in Denmark looked at billing information from 358,000 cell phone users and then compared it to brain-tumor data from a national cancer registry. That study did not find a link between the two. <a href=\"http:\/\/www.cancerepidemiology.net\/article\/S1877-7821(16)30050-9\/abstract\" target=\"_blank\">Another recent study<\/a> published in May looked at incidence of brain cancer in Australia from 1982 to 2013 and did not find an uptick in cancer cases with the introduction of cells phones. Still, <a href=\"http:\/\/healthland.time.com\/2011\/02\/22\/study-cell-phones-cause-changes-in-brain-activity\/\">other government-funded studies<\/a> have made connections between cell phones’ electromagnetic fields and changes in brain activity. <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/2850594\/guys-your-smartphone-is-hurting-your-sperm\/\">And a June 2014 study<\/a> found that radiation from cell phones can lower men’s sperm mobility by 8% and sperm viability by 9%.<\/p>\n<p>The NIH <a href=\"http:\/\/www.cancer.gov\/about-cancer\/causes-prevention\/risk\/radiation\/cell-phones-fact-sheet\" target=\"_blank\">says<\/a> part of the reason research so far has been inconsistent is that there are various factors that can influence the results of a study. For instance, brain cancers are notoriously difficult to study due to their high mortality rates, and studies are also subject to issues like inaccurate reporting. There are also changes over time in the type of cell phones available as well as how much people use them.<\/p>\n<p>The researchers say this new report is unlikely to be the final word on the possible risks of cell phone radiation, and more data from their research is anticipated to be released in fall Dec. 16, while wearing the “We Matter” jersey, the Sixers and Streeter said in statements on Saturday.<\/p>\n<p>“After thoughtful conversation, the 76ers and Sevyn Streeter have worked together to develop a plan we hope will bring meaningful action in the Philadelphia Community,” the team said in its statement, adding that it plans to donate to the Boys and Girls Clubs of Philadelphia and collaborate with Streeter on community outreach programs in the city.<\/p>\n<p>The team originally cancelled Streeter’s Oct. 26 performance and <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4549487\/76ers-apologize-sevyn-streeter-national-anthem\/?iid=sr-link2\" target=\"_blank\">later apologized<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>“After receiving feedback from our players, basketball operations staff and ownership group, we believe that the wrong decision was made, and Sevyn should have been welcomed to sing,” the organization said in a statement on Oct. 28.<\/p>\n<p>Athletes and performers at sporting events across the country have been kneeling during the national anthem in recent months, a movement started by <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4504023\/athletes-america-patriotism\/\" target=\"_blank\">San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick<\/a> to protest racial discrimination and police violence.<\/p>\n<p>“<span class=\"s1\">After a meaningful dialogue with the 76ers organization, <\/span>I have accepted their apology,” Streeter said in her statement Saturday. “In order to move
